Journal.Title: Water science and technology : a journal of the International Association on Water Pollution Research

Article.ArticleTitle: Effects of untreated or insufficiently treated wastewater discharges on the spatial and temporal variability of nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O) emissions from different streams in southeastern Brazil.

AbstractText: Increasing atmospheric N<sub>2</sub>O concentrations is of great environmental concern due to the role of this gas in climate change and stratospheric ozone destruction. Nitrogen-enriched lotic water bodies are significant sources of N<sub>2</sub>O. However, N<sub>2</sub>O emissions from rivers and streams, particularly those that receive untreated or insufficiently treated wastewater discharge, are poorly understood, especially in Brazil. The present study investigated the effects of the discharge of untreated or insufficiently treated wastewater on the spatial-temporal variability of N<sub>2</sub>O emissions from different streams in Ilha Grande, located within the Abraão hydrographic system, in southeastern Brazil. Estimated N<sub>2</sub>O fluxes determined in Abraão streams and upstream of the urbanized stretch ranged from 18.4 and 96.5 μg N m<sup>-2</sup> h<sup>-1</sup>. Inside the urbanized stretch, estimated N<sub>2</sub>O fluxes ranged from 110 to 561 μg N m<sup>-2</sup> h<sup>-1</sup> under non-limited dissolved oxygen (DO) conditions and 133 to 2,229 μg N m<sup>-2</sup> h<sup>-1</sup> under hypoxic conditions (DO < 2 mg O<sub>2</sub> L<sup>-1</sup>). High spatial and temporal variability in N<sub>2</sub>O emissions were noted, with the highest emissions in Abraão urban areas. Therefore, the differences observed between N<sub>2</sub>O fluxes from the studied streams at Abraão seem to be associated with different lotic water body conditions, such as availability of reactive N and DO.
